REST API documentation¶

Add your content using reStructuredText syntax. See the reStructuredText documentation for details.

REST API main¶

async main.add_process_time_header(request: Request, call_next)¶

The add_process_time_header function adds a header to the response called &quot;My-Process-Time&quot; that contains the time it took for this function to run. This is useful for debugging purposes.

Parameters:

  • request (Request) – Access the request object.

  • call_next – Call the next middleware in the chain.

Returns:

The response object.

async main.healthchecker(db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶

The healthchecker function is a simple function that checks the health of the database. It does this by making a request to the database and checking if it returns any results. If there are no results, then we know something is wrong with our connection to the database.

Parameters:

db (Session) – The database session.

Returns:

A dictionary with a message key

main.index()¶

The read_root function is a simple function that returns a dictionary with the key &quot;message&quot; and value &quot;REST APP v-0.0&quot;. This function is used to test if the REST API server is running.

Returns:

A dictionary with a single key/value pair

async main.startup()¶

The startup function is called when the application starts up. It’s a good place to initialize things that are used by the app, such as databases or caches.

Returns:

A future object, which is a special type of object that represents the result of an asynchronous operation

REST API Users¶

async users.confirmed_email(email: str, db: Session) → None¶

The confirmed_email function takes in an email and a database session, and sets the confirmed field of the user with that email to True.

Parameters:

  • email (str) – Pass in the email of the user that is being confirmed

  • db (Session) – The database session.

Returns:

None

Return type:

None

async users.create_user(body: UserModel, db: Session) → User¶
The create_user function creates a new user in the database.
Args:

body (UserModel): The UserModel object containing the data to be inserted into the database.

Parameters:

  • body (UserModel) – Validate the data that is passed in.

  • db (Session) – The database session.

Returns:

The new user object.

Return type:

User

async users.get_user_by_email(email: str, db: Session) → User | None¶

The get_user_by_email function takes in an email and a database session, and returns the user associated with that email. If no such user exists, it returns None.

Parameters:

  • email (str) – Pass the email of the user to be retrieved.

  • db (Session) – The database session.

Returns:

A user object if the user exists, and none if it doesn’t.

Return type:

User | None

async users.update_avatar(email: str, url: str, db: Session) → User¶

The update_avatar function updates the avatar of a user.

Parameters:

  • email (str) – Find the user in the database

  • url (str) – Specify the type of data that is being passed into the function

  • db (Session) – The database session.

Returns:

A user object

Return type:

User

async users.update_token(user: User, token: str | None, db: Session) → None¶

The update_token function updates the refresh token for a user.

Parameters:

  • user (User) – Get the user’s id, which is used to find the user in the database

  • token (str | None) – Update the refresh token in the database

  • db (Session) – The database session.

Returns:

None

Return type:

None

async users.update_user_password(email: str, password: str, db: Session) → User¶
The update_user_password function updates a user’s password in the database.
Args:

email (str): The email of the user to update. password (str): The new password for the user.

Parameters:

  • email (str) – Find the user in the database and update their password

  • password (str) – Pass the new password to the function

  • db (Session) – The database session.

Returns:

The updated user

Return type:

User

REST API Contacts¶

async contacts.create_contact(body: ContactSchema, user: User, db: Session) → Contact¶
Creates a new contact in the database for a specific user.
Args:

body (ContactModel): The contact to create. user (User): The current user, who is creating the contact.

Parameters:

  • body (ContactSchema) – The data for the contact to create.

  • user (User) – The user to create the contact for.

  • db (Session) – The database session.

Returns:

The contact object.

Return type:

Contact

async contacts.delete_contact(contact_id: int, user: User, db: Session) → Contact | None¶
Removes a single contact with the specified ID for a specific user.
Args:

contact_id (int): The id of the contact to be removed. user (User): The user who is removing the contact. This is used to ensure that only contacts belonging to this user are deleted, and not contacts belonging to other users with similar IDs.

Parameters:

  • contact_id (int) – The ID of the contact to remove.

  • user (User) – The user to remove the contact for.

  • db (Session) – The database session.

Returns:

The removed contact, or None if it does not exist.

Return type:

Contact | None

async contacts.get_contact(contact_id: int, user: User, db: Session) → Contact | None¶
Retrieves a single contact with the specified ID for a specific user.
Args:

contact_id (int): The id of the desired Contact. user (User): The User who owns the desired Contact.

Parameters:

  • contact_id (int) – The ID of the contact to retrieve.

  • user (User) – The user to retrieve the contact for.

  • db (Session) – The database session.

Returns:

The contact with the specified ID, or None if it does not exist.

Return type:

Contact | None

async contacts.get_contacts(contact_field: str, user: User, db: Session) → List[Contact] | Contact¶
Retrieves a list of contacts for a specific user with specified search parameters.
Args:

contact_field (str): The parameter for search of the desired Contact. user (User): The User who owns the desired Contact.

Parameters:

  • contact_field (str) – contact field by which we search.

  • user (User) – The user to retrieve contacts for.

  • db (Session) – The database session.

Returns:

A list of contacts.

Return type:

List[Contact] | Contact

async contacts.get_contacts_birthdays(user: User, db: Session) → List[Contact]¶

The birthday_list function takes a user and database session as arguments. It returns a list of contacts whose birthdays are within the next 7 days.

Args:

user (User): The current user, used for authorization purposes.

Parameters:

  • user – User: Get the user id from the database

  • db – Session: Access the database

Returns:

A list of contacts with birthdays in the next week

async contacts.update_contact(contact_id: int, body: ContactSchema, user: User, db: Session) → Contact | None¶
Updates a single contact with the specified ID for a specific user.
Args:

contact_id (int): The id of the contact to update. body (ContactModel): The updated contact information. user (User): The current user, used for authorization purposes.

Parameters:

  • contact_id (int) – The ID of the contact to update.

  • body (ContactSchema) – The updated data for the contact.

  • user (User) – The user to update the contact for.

  • db (Session) – The database session.

Returns:

The updated contact, or None if it does not exist.

Return type:

Contact | None

REST API Auth¶

class auth.Auth¶

Bases: object

ALGORITHM = 'HS256'¶
SECRET_KEY = 'secret_key'¶
async create_access_token(data: dict, expires_delta: float | None = None) → str¶
The create_access_token function creates a new access token.
Args:

data (dict): A dictionary containing the claims to be encoded in the JWT. expires_delta (Optional[float]): An optional parameter specifying how long, in seconds, the access token should last before expiring. If not specified, it defaults to 15 minutes.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of the class.

  • data (dict) – Pass the data that will be encoded in the jwt.

  • expires_delta (Optional[float]) – Set the expiration time of the access token.

Returns:

A token that is encoded with the data.

Return type:

str

create_email_token(data: dict) → str¶

The create_email_token function takes a dictionary of data and returns a token. The token is created by encoding the data with the SECRET_KEY and ALGORITHM, and adding an iat (issued at) timestamp and exp (expiration) timestamp to it.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of the class.

  • data (dict) – Pass in the data that will be encoded into a jwt.

Returns:

A token that is encoded with the user’s email address and a secret key.

Return type:

str

async create_refresh_token(data: dict, expires_delta: float | None = None) → str¶
The create_refresh_token function creates a refresh token for the user.
Args:

data (dict): A dictionary containing the user’s id and username. expires_delta (Optional[float]): The number of seconds until the token expires, defaults to None.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of the class.

  • data (dict) – Pass the user data that will be encoded in the jwt.

  • expires_delta (Optional[float]) – Set the time that a token is valid for.

Returns:

A token that can be used to refresh the access token.

Return type:

str

async decode_refresh_token(refresh_token: str) → str¶

The decode_refresh_token function is used to decode the refresh token. It takes in a refresh_token as an argument and returns the email of the user who owns that token. If there is no such user, it raises an HTTPException with status code 401 (Unauthorized) and detail ‘Could not validate credentials’.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of a class.

  • refresh_token (str) – Pass in the refresh token that is sent with the request.

Returns:

The email of the user.

Return type:

str

async get_current_user(token: str = Depends(OAuth2PasswordBearer), db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶
The get_current_user function is a dependency that will be used in the

UserRouter class. It takes in a token and db session, and returns the user associated with that token. If no user is found, it raises an exception.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of the class.

  • token (str) – Get the token from the header of our request.

  • db (Session) – The database session.

Returns:

The user object.

Return type:

User

async get_email_from_token(token: str) → str¶

The get_email_from_token function takes a token as an argument and returns the email address associated with that token. The function uses the jwt library to decode the token, which is then used to return the email address.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of the class.

  • token (str) – Pass the token to the function.

Returns:

The email address of the user who is trying to verify their account.

Return type:

str

get_password_hash(password: str) → str¶

The get_password_hash function takes a password as input and returns the hash of that password. The hash is generated using the pwd_context object, which is an instance of Flask-Bcrypt’s Bcrypt class.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of the class.

  • password (str) – Pass the password that will be hashed.

Returns:

A hash of the password.

Return type:

str

oauth2_scheme = <fastapi.security.oauth2.OAuth2PasswordBearer object>¶
pwd_context = <CryptContext>¶
r = <redis.client.Redis(<redis.connection.ConnectionPool(<redis.connection.Connection(host=localhost,port=6379,db=0)>)>)>¶
verify_password(plain_password, hashed_password) → bool¶

The verify_password function takes a plain-text password and hashed password as arguments. It then uses the pwd_context object to verify that the plain-text password matches the hashed one.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of the class.

  • plain_password (str) – Pass the password that is entered by the user.

  • hashed_password (str) – Store the hashed password in the database.

Returns:

True or false depending on whether the password is correct.

Return type:

bool

REST API User_email¶

async user_email.send_email(email: EmailStr, username: str, host: str)¶
The send_email function sends an email to the user with a link to confirm their email address.
The function takes in three parameters:

-email (EmailStr): the user’s email address. -username (str): the username of the user who is registering for an account. This will be used in a greeting message within the body of the email sent to them. -host (str): this is where we are hosting our application (i.e., localhost). This will be used as part of a URL that users can click on within their emails.

Parameters:

  • email (EmailStr) – Validate the email address.

  • username (str) – Get the username of the user.

  • host (str) – Send the host to the email template.

Returns:

A coroutine object, which is an awaitable.

async user_email.send_email_password(email: EmailStr, username: str, host: str)¶
The send_email_password function sends an email to the user with a link to reset their password.
Args:

email (str): The user’s email address. username (str): The user’s username. host (str): The host of the website, used for generating links in emails.

Parameters:

  • email (EmailStr) – Specify the email address of the recipient.

  • username (str) – Pass the username to the template.

  • host (str) – Create the link to the reset password page.

Returns:

A coroutine object.

REST API My_routes¶

async my_routes.create_contact(body: ContactSchema, db: Session = Depends(get_db), current_user: User = Depends(get_current_user))¶
Creates a new contact in the database for a specific user.
Args:

body (ContactModel): The contact to create. db (Session): A database session object used for querying and updating data in the database using SQLAlchemy’s ORM methods. current_user (User): The current user, who is creating the contact.

Parameters:

  • body (ContactSchema) – The data for the contact to create.

  • db (Session) – The database session.

  • current_user (User) – The user to create the contact for.

Returns:

The contact object.

Return type:

Contact

async my_routes.delete_contact(contact_id: int, db: Session = Depends(get_db), current_user: User = Depends(get_current_user))¶
Removes a single contact with the specified ID for a specific user.
Args:

contact_id (int): The id of the contact to be removed. user (User): The user who is removing the contact. This is used to ensure that only contacts belonging to this user are deleted, and not contacts belonging to other users with similar IDs.

Parameters:

  • contact_id (int) – The ID of the contact to remove.

  • db (Session) – The database session.

  • current_user (User) – The user to remove the contact for.

Returns:

The removed contact, or None if it does not exist.

Return type:

Contact | None

async my_routes.get_contact(contact_id: int, db: Session = Depends(get_db), current_user: User = Depends(get_current_user))¶
Retrieves a single contact with the specified ID for a specific user.
Args:

contact_id (int): The id of the desired Contact. db (Session): A database session object used for querying and updating data in the database using SQLAlchemy’s ORM methods. current_user (User): The User who owns the desired Contact.

Parameters:

  • contact_id (int) – The ID of the contact to retrieve.

  • db (Session) – The database session.

  • current_user (User) – The user to retrieve the contact for.

Returns:

The contact with the specified ID, or None if it does not exist.

Return type:

Contact | None

async my_routes.get_contacts(contact_field: str = Query(None), db: Session = Depends(get_db), current_user: User = Depends(get_current_user))¶

The get_contacts function returns a list of contacts for the current user. May search_field function searches for a contacts in the database. It takes a string as an argument and returns all contacts that contain this string in any of their fields. If no such contacts are found, it raises an HTTPException with status code 404.

Args:

contact_field (str): The parameter for search of the desired Contact. db (Session): A database session object used for querying and updating data in the database using SQLAlchemy’s ORM methods. current_user (User): The User who owns the desired Contact.

Parameters:

  • contact_field (str) – The parameter for search of the desired Contact.

  • db (Session) – The database session.

  • current_user (User) – Get the current user from the auth_service.

Returns:

A list of contacts

Return type:

List[Contact]

async my_routes.get_contacts_birthdays(db: Session = Depends(get_db), current_user: User = Depends(get_current_user))¶

The birthday_list function takes a user and database session as arguments. It returns a list of contacts whose birthdays are within the next 7 days.

Args:

user (User): The current user, used for authorization purposes.

Parameters:

  • user – User: Get the user id from the database

  • db – Session: Access the database

Returns:

A list of contacts with birthdays in the next week

async my_routes.update_contact(body: ContactSchema, contact_id: int, db: Session = Depends(get_db), current_user: User = Depends(get_current_user))¶
The update_contact function updates a contact in the database.
The function takes three arguments:

body (ContactSchema): object containing the new values for the contact. contact_id (int): An integer representing the id of an existing contact to be updated. db (Session): A database session object used for querying and updating data in the database using SQLAlchemy’s ORM methods. current_user (User): The current user, who is creating the contact.

Parameters:

body – Get the contact data from the request body.

:type body : ContactSchema :param contact_id: Specify the id of the contact to update. :type contact_id: int :param db: The database session. :type db: Session :param current_user: Get the current user. :type current_user: User :return: The updated contact :rtype: Contact

REST API Users_routes¶

async users_routes.read_users_me(current_user: User = Depends(get_current_user)) → User¶
The read_users_me function is a GET endpoint that returns the current user’s information.
Args:
current_user (User): The user whose avatar is being updated. This is passed in by the auth_service dependency,

which uses JWT tokens to authenticate users and pass them into functions that require authentication. See auth_service for more details on how this works.

Parameters:

current_user (User) – Pass the current user to the function.

Returns:

The current user object.

Return type:

User

async users_routes.update_avatar_user(file: UploadFile = File(PydanticUndefined), current_user: User = Depends(get_current_user), db: Session = Depends(get_db)) → User¶
The update_avatar_user function updates the avatar of a user.
Args:

file (UploadFile): The image to be uploaded as an avatar. current_user (User): The user whose avatar is being updated. This is passed in by the auth_service dependency, which uses JWT tokens to authenticate users and pass them into functions that require authentication. See auth_service for more details on how this works. db (Session): A database session object used for querying and updating data in the database using SQLAlchemy’s ORM methods.

Parameters:

  • file (UploadFile) – Upload the file to cloudinary.

  • current_user (User) – Get the current user’s email and username.

  • db (Session) – The database session.

Returns:

A user object

Return type:

User

async users_routes.update_password_user(password, background_tasks: BackgroundTasks, request: Request, current_user: User = Depends(get_current_user), db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶
The update_password_user function updates the password of a user.

The function takes in the new password, and returns the updated user object.

Parameters:

  • password (str) – Get the password from the request body.

  • background_tasks (BackgroundTasks) – Add a task to the background queue.

  • request (Request) – Get the base url of the server.

  • current_user (User) – Get the current user.

  • db (Session) – The database session.

Returns:

The user object.

Return type:

User

REST API Auth_routes¶

async auth_routes.confirmed_email(token: str, db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶
The confirmed_email function is used to confirm a user’s email address.

It takes the token from the URL and uses it to get the user’s email address. The function then checks if there is a user with that email in our database, and if not, returns an error message. If there is a user with that email in our database, we check whether its account has already been confirmed or not. If it has been confirmed already, we return another message saying so; otherwise we call repository_users’ confirmed_email function which sets the ‘confirmed’ field of that particular record to True

Parameters:

  • token (str) – Get the token from the url.

  • db (Session) – The database session.

Returns:

A message that the email has been confirmed.

Return type:

dict

async auth_routes.login(body: OAuth2PasswordRequestForm = Depends(NoneType), db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶
The login function is used to authenticate a user.

It takes the username and password from the request body, verifies them against the database, and returns an access token if successful.

Parameters:

  • body (OAuth2PasswordRequestForm) – Get the username and password from the request body.

  • db (Session) – The database session.

Returns:

The access token and refresh token.

Return type:

dict

async auth_routes.refresh_token(credentials: HTTPAuthorizationCredentials = Security(HTTPBearer), db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶
The refresh_token function is used to refresh the access token.

The function takes in a refresh token and returns an access_token, a new refresh_token, and the type of token. If the user’s current refresh_token does not match what was passed into this function then it will return an error.

Parameters:

  • credentials (HTTPAuthorizationCredentials) – Get the token from the request header.

  • db (Session) – The database session.

Returns:

A dictionary with the access_token, refresh_token and token type.

Return type:

dict

async auth_routes.request_email(body: RequestEmail, background_tasks: BackgroundTasks, request: Request, db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶

The request_email function is used to send an email to the user with a link that they can click on to confirm their email address. The function takes in a RequestEmail object, which contains the email of the user who wants to confirm their account. It then checks if there is already a confirmed user with that email address, and if so returns an error message saying as much. If not, it sends an email containing a confirmation link.

Parameters:

  • body (RequestEmail) – Get the email from the request body.

  • background_tasks (BackgroundTasks) – Add a task to the background tasks queue.

  • request (Request) – Get the base url of the server.

  • db (Session) – The database session.

Returns:

A message to the user

Return type:

dict

async auth_routes.signup(body: UserModel, background_tasks: BackgroundTasks, request: Request, db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶
The signup function creates a new user in the database.

It takes a UserModel object as input, which is validated by pydantic. If the email address already exists in the database, an HTTP 409 error is raised. The password field of the UserModel object is hashed using Argon2 and stored in that form. A new user record is created with this information and returned to the client.

Parameters:

  • body (UserModel) – Get the body of the request.

  • background_tasks (BackgroundTasks) – Add a task to the background tasks queue.

  • request (Request) – Get the base url of the server.

  • db (Session) – The database session.

Returns:

A dictionary with two keys: user and detail.

Return type:

dict
